Trump signals he may soon lower rates on China and rest of the world. President to invite top investors in his meme coin to a private gala. V.P. Vance threatens U.S. could walk away from ceasefire talks. White House signals U.S. could "walk away" from ceasefire talks. Thousands flock to St. Peter`s Basilica to bid farewell to pontiff. New Jersey Fire could still grow to the largest in state history. It is not known if mother and daughter`s death related to serial killer case. Ed Sheeran and Noah Kahan give impromptu concert in Nashville bar. Tennessee Parole Board recommends pardon for country music star, Jelly Roll. How changes to student loan repayment could impact millions. FBI Report: Scammers stole record $16.6 billion from Americans in 2024. Tony trades tie for a toolbelt in mission to build his wife a house. Chef and humanitarian, Jose Andres on new book, "Change the Recipe" about life lessons. Hugh Jackman and Hugh Evans on Summit to fight extreme poverty. Hugh Jackman and Hugh Evans on summit to fight extreme poverty. Music legend, Smokey Robinson music legend on career and new album "What The World Needs Now."

GAYLE KING: Trump is for your Thursday, as we welcome you to CBS MORNINGS. I`m Gayle King.

TONY DOKOUPIL: I`m Tony Dokoupil.

NATE BURLESON: And I`m Nate Burleson.

We`ve got big news on President Trump`s trade war with China.

GAYLE KING: And we`re also following one of the worst northeast wildfires in recent years. But first, here`s today`s "Eye Opener." It`s your world in 90 seconds.

A major shift from President Trump on China, he says he may reduce tariffs after growing economic backlash. We`ll have the latest for you.

NANCY CORDES: How soon do you want to bring the tariffs on China`s --

DONALD TRUMP (R) (President of the United States of America): Well, that depends on them.

TONY DOKOUPIL: The faithful line up to pay their final respects as Pope Francis lies in state.

SETH DOANE: Can you describe your feeling when you were inside?

SARAH BORCHER (Visiting from Cincinnati): It was a little bit overwhelming.

NATE BURLESON: New Jersey faces what could become its worst wildfire in decades, with thousands of homes and businesses under threat.

ROB NOSTI ("Liberty Door and Awning" president): Pure devastation. You know, this is a complete start over.

REPORTER #1: The Tennessee Board of Parole is recommending a pardon for country music singer, Jelly Roll for crimes he committed before his music career.

REPORTER #2: Well, Chipotle is headed to Mexico. The American burrito chain has inked a deal to launch its first location in Mexico early next year.

JIMMY KIMMEL ("Jimmy Kimmel Live" host): I am excited for them to try what we think Mexican food is.

(Clip from "Sunset Boulevard" on Broadway)

REPORTER: The show must go on. Actor, Nicole Scherzinger grabbing a bull horn to belt out a tune from "Sunset Boulevard" when the sound system failed during yesterday`s Broadway matinee.

(Clip from "Sunset Boulevard" on Broadway)

ANNOUNCER: This morning`s "Eye Opener" is presented by Progressive, making it easy to bundle insurance.

GAYLE KING: Well, that was yesterday at the matinee. Oprah and I went to the show last night. I`m still floating from what I saw from her on the stage last night. She is beyond, beyond good.

TONY DOKOUPIL: I`m excited. We`re going to go next week. So they got the lights working.

GAYLE KING: Yes, because she is coming here.

NATE BURLESON: Yes.

GAYLE KING: She`s coming here.

TONY DOKOUPIL: They got the lights working by the evening.

GAYLE KING: Yes, they did. I can`t wait for you guys to see the show. She`s amazing.

Hello, and welcome to CBS MORNINGS.

Today`s show is packed. I love days like this. Take a look -- don`t you?

TONY DOKOUPIL: Oh, yes.

NATE BURLESON: Oh.

GAYLE KING: I love days like this. Take a look at the lineup. Hugh Jackman, Smokey Robinson, and Chef Jose Andres, just to name a few.

NATE BURLESON: And also, it`s Tony`s turn in our series, "Never Too Late," where you can watch a grown man learn how to swing a hammer and I`m not talking about Thor, but you will marvel at how good he looks.

GAYLE KING: I`m trying to figure out -- I`m trying to figure out what he was blowing.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Okay, a little -- a little saw dust in the arm here I find quite the aphrodisiac when you go home for the evening, I`ll say that.

NATE BURLESON: Hey, now.

TONY DOKOUPIL: All coming up in the eight o`clock hour.

NATE BURLESON: Good morning to everyone at home.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Let`s get to the news, why don`t we? We`re going to begin with what appears to be good news, possibly a reversal from President Trump on the trade war with China, it could help the economy, it could help the markets.

Yesterday, the President appeared to be softening his tone on what had been some very steep China tariffs, but at the very same time, he hinted that more tariffs could be put in place unless countries make deals with the U.S. in the weeks ahead.

Ed O`Keefe is at the White House. He has been following this daily seesaw, the whiplash and the back and forth.

Ed, good morning to you.

On that subject, we`ve got China responding this morning. What are they saying now?

ED O`KEEFE: I`m still shaking my head about what you said about arm hair, Tony, but good morning.

Overnight, Beijing said that if the U.S. doesn`t start -- if he really wants to resolve this issue, it should cancel tariffs on China, and that comes as President Trump signals he is easing off his tough tariff policies in recent days, saying his administration`s talked with 90 countries about trade deals.

(Begin VT)

ED O`KEEFE: What went down is coming back up. Stocks on the rebound around the world, President Trump signals high tariffs on China are set to end soon.

PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: I get along very well with President Xi, and I hope we can make a deal.

ED O`KEEFE: But it came with a warning to China and other countries that without a deal, the White House will set a price.

PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: That will happen, I`d say over the next couple of weeks. Wouldn`t you say? I think so, over the next two, three weeks, we`ll be setting the number.

ED O`KEEFE: Trump`s moves come after weeks of global economic instability. This week, the CEOs of top retailers, Walmart and Target, privately warned the President tariffs could disrupt global supply chains to result in empty shelves in the coming weeks.

And Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent sought to calm nerves by telling a meeting hosted by JPMorgan Chase, there will be de-escalation with China.

On Wednesday, addressing leaders in international finance, he said the U.S. is merely trying to rebalance global trade.

SCOTT BESSENT (U.S. Treasury Secretary): America first does not mean America alone. To the contrary, it is a call for deeper collaboration and mutual respect among trade partners.

ED O`KEEFE: While President Trump says there`s been direct contact daily between the U.S. and China on trade --

(MAN speaking in foreign language.)

ED O`KEEFE: This morning, China`s Ministry of Commerce pushed back, saying "Any claims about the progress of China-U.S. trade negotiations are groundless as trying to catch the wind and have no factual basis."

(End VT)

ED O`KEEFE: And now 12 Democratic controlled states are suing the President to stop his tariffs. Arizona is one of the states, and its Attorney General called the tariffs insane and illegal, because the President can only set tariffs if there`s an extraordinary threat against the country. They argue there isn`t, and so that`s why they`re suing -- Tony.

TONY DOKOUPIL: All right, Ed, while we have you, you know, President Trump has made a career out of leveraging his personal brand, his personal name, but now there are new ethics questions around a meme coin that could lead to a private dinner with the President. What can you tell us about this?

ED O`KEEFE: Yes, this is an interesting one. It has to do with the President`s meme coin, cryptocurrency, which got a major boost after its website posted an announcement offering a "intimate, private dinner with President Trump" at his golf club out in Virginia next month. The catch, it will go to 220 people who buy the most Trump cryptocurrency in the next few weeks, and the top 25 get to meet the President at a private VIP reception.

He launched the so-called meme coin just days before the inauguration, and is controlled by businesses linked to him, meaning the President stands to profit, at least on paper when the price increases.

The latest move of the President in this room has ethics watch dogs and Democrats crying foul. Senator Chris Murphy, for example, called it the most brazenly corrupt thing a president has ever done. Part of the concern, Tony is who exactly spends the money to get in the room with the President to try to influence him on policy? That`s what has people so concerned. And are they American business leaders? Are they someone else? Are they foreigners, potentially getting in there and getting some time with the President?

TONY DOKOUPIL: Could be anyone.

Ed, thank you very much.

NATE BURLESON: All right, let`s move along to one of the conflicts abroad. The President is taking a tough line with Ukraine, accusing President Zelenskyy of undermining talks for a ceasefire with Russia.

Vice President J.D. Vance says Russia and Ukraine need to say yes to an American peace proposal or the U.S. will walk away.

Zelenskyy objects to giving up territory to Russia under the plan, and the war isn`t stopping. Overnight, Russia launched a deadly new attack on Ukraine`s capital.

Holly Williams has more.

(Begin VT)

HOLLY WILLIAMS: Russia killed Ukrainian civilians again last night, hitting residential areas according to Ukrainian officials. At least nine people lost their lives.

(OKSANA BILLAZIR speaking in foreign language.)

HOLLY WILLIAMS: "Diplomacy won`t work here," said Oksana Billazir (sp?). "There simply aren`t words to express what a monster Vladimir Putin is."

But President Trump said yesterday that he`s not taking sides.

PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: I have no favorites. I don`t want to have any favorites. I want to have a deal done.

HOLLY WILLIAMS: In the more than three years since Putin started this war, the U.S. has supported Ukraine with over $100 billion in aid, but now the White House says the President`s patience is wearing thin as he pushes a peace plan that reportedly involves excluding Ukraine from NATO membership, freezing the fighting close to the current frontline and recognizing Crimea as part of Russia.

The Russians seized Crimea by force the first time Putin invaded in 2014. Ukraine`s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy says officially recognizing Russia`s occupation would be against his country`s constitution.

In February, the U.S. briefly suspended military aid to Ukraine after this fiery meeting at the White House.

PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: You don`t have the cards right now.

HOLLY WILLIAMS: The fear in Ukraine is that if President Trump doesn`t get what he wants, the U.S. could permanently cut off its help.

(End VT)

HOLLY WILLIAMS: The Trump administration`s peace plan reportedly also includes relief from sanctions for Russia. Now, some fear that rewarding Vladimir Putin with economic help and territory could encourage him to invade Ukraine again in the future or even target other countries -- Gayle.

GAYLE KING: Holly, thank you so much.

In Rome, the outpouring of people wanting to see Pope Francis lying in state is so big, so huge the Vatican had to keep St. Peter`s Basilica open all night long. Officially, nearly 50,000 mourners filed past the Pope`s coffin in the first 24 hours of public display. One of them was our senior foreign correspondent, Seth Doane.

(Begin VT)

SETH DOANE: The masses today came in the form of the hushed faithful inching closer to have their moment with Pope Francis.

Sarah Borcher (sp?) is from Cincinnati and her family waited in line for five hours.

SETH DOANE: How has it struck you?

SARAH BORCHER: It struck me as there`s almost a sense of uncertainty. We don`t know who is going to be elected Pope next.

SETH DOANE: That`s what Cardinals meeting daily are starting to discuss.

JOHN ALLEN ("Crux" editor): Every papal Conclave comes down, in some sense, to a referendum on the papacy that has just ended.

SETH DOANE: John Allen is the editor of "Crux," a news site specializing in the Vatican.

Is it too early to know if there are front runners?

JOHN ALLEN: It is never too early to talk about whether or not there are front runners.

SETH DOANE: In keeping continuity with Pope Francis` ministry, Allen says one bet would be the Vatican`s number two.

JOHN ALLEN: Cardinal Pietro Parolin, an Italian currently the Vatican Secretary of State.

SETH DOANE: He`s a tested top diplomat.

JOHN ALLEN: Another strong continuity candidate would be Cardinal Matteo Zuppi, currently the Cardinal of Bologna.

He was appointed by Pope Francis as his personal troubleshooter for the conflict in Ukraine, so he too has diplomatic experience.

Now, if you want a change, perhaps a change in a slightly more traditional conservative direction than Francis would be Cardinal Peter Erdo of Budapest in Hungary. Church lawyer by training, brilliant guy.

Another possibility would be Cardinal Fridolin Ambongo, who is the cardinal with Kinshasa in Congo.

SETH DOANE: He also was vocal in pushing against Pope Francis` decision to bless same sex unions.

(WOMAN speaking in foreign language.)

SETH DOANE: And for a compromise candidate --

JOHN ALLEN: Cardinal Pierre Batista Pizzaballa, who is currently the Latin right Patriarch of Jerusalem, meaning the top Catholic in the Holy Land. His name in Italian, literally means "pizza dance." Imagine the memes should we get Papa Pizza Dance?

(End VT)

SETH DOANE: Now, he is a serious contender, in part because how he`s seen, really as someone who can help bridge divides in the Middle East. Now, this process of picking a Pope is intriguing, and one way of gaging interest, even in fictionalized form, take a look at the streaming figures for the film "Conclave," up 283 percent on Monday after Pope Francis died -- Tony.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Yes, I plan to watch it in the days ahead. Seth Doane from Rome for us. Seth, thank you very much. Appreciate it.

Turning now to a wildfire that has now burned more than 13,000 acres in Southern New Jersey. Firefighters are making progress, however, with containment now up to 50 percent, but officials warn this could still become the state`s biggest wildfire in decades.

Nikki Battiste is out there covering the story.

(Begin VT)

MAN: It`s way bigger than I thought.

NIKKI BATTISTE: A growing wildfire in Southern New Jersey, sending plumes of smoke above neighborhoods in Ocean County has left some people who live there on edge, including Aimee Zettel who was allowed back home after an earlier evacuation order.

AIMEE ZETTEL (Lacey Township, New Jersey resident): It`s a nerve wracking feeling. It`s unsettling just because we could go back home. I didn`t even put any of my stuff back in the house. It`s like in the garage and bags, just in case.

NIKKI BATTISTE: While firefighters are finally starting to get control of the blaze that quadrupled in size in the span of 24 hours, the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection says it could be the worst wildfire in 20 years.

BILL DONNELLY (New Jersey Forest Fire Service chief): Our objective is to starve the fire so that when the fire arrives into the area, there`s nothing left to burn.

MAN: Oh, it took a building on fire.

NIKKI BATTISTE: Multiple structures are in the path of the fire, which blackened and almost completely burned this home while reducing this small business to rubble.

ROB NOSTI You think you know what you`re going to walk into until you walk into it and it`s -- there`s not one thing that survived. It is pure devastation. You know, this is complete start over, but we will.

NIKKI BATTISTE: For CBS MORNINGS, Nikki Battiste, New York.

(End VT)

TONY DOKOUPIL: Smoke from that wildfire is spreading across multiple states, leading to some urgent air quality alerts. Meteorologist, Kate Bilo from CBS News, Philadelphia is tracking where it`s all headed.

Kate, good morning.

KATE BILO: Good morning to you, Tony.

Yes, here in Philadelphia, we are tracking that fire and that smoke plume very, very closely. In fact, as I kind of open the walls here, you can see a little bit of a haze over the city skyline here in Philadelphia. But let`s take a look at where the smoke is, of course, centered on that Jones Road Fire, which is just south of Toms River New Jersey.

And most of the smoke this morning, we`ve been seeing it kind of lift up into portions of Long Island in New York City. There is some indication that another plume of at least elevated smoke and haze could impact the I- 95 Corridor this afternoon, but with the southwest flow, it looks like Long Island, New York City will kind of be in that threat zone for air quality problems through today, and air quality alerts are in effect for this region.

We will eventually get some relief from this, luckily, as we head into the weekend, but the system that`s going to bring the relief, bring the relief is also bringing some problems, especially to portions of the Central and Southern Plains today.

We have an enhanced risk of flash flooding, where you see this yellow, basically from the Dallas0Fort Worth Metro right on up into portions of Nebraska, Kansas, where you see the yellow, that`s where storms are bringing heavy, heavy downpours, rainfall rates of an inch or two per hour, leading to the risk for flash flooding. You can see these big clusters of heavy storms.

This, though, is the same system that`s going to head into the northeast by the weekend, and it is going to produce a good soaking, which is great news for fire crews in our region.

Tony. I`ll send it back to you.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Kate Bilo for us. Kate, thank you.

NATE BURLESON: It is now day three of the retrial of Karen Read, the Massachusetts woman accused of killing her police officer boyfriend.

Yesterday, the Court heard witness testimony, including from O`Keefe`s mother, speaking publicly about her son`s death. For the first time. Read has pleaded not guilty to the charges.

Jordyn Jagolinzer from CBS News Boston reports.

(Begin VT)

PEGGY O`KEEFE (John O`Keefe`s mother): He was bruised up. His eyes were closed. Just not a good scene.

JORDYN JAGOLINZER: Peggy O`Keefe described seeing her son, John, in the hospital where he was pronounced dead after he was found unresponsive in a snow bank, and then her interaction with his girlfriend, Karen Read.

PEGGY O`KEEFE: As I`m walking down, I hear Karen Read yell, "Peg, is he dead? Is he dead, Peg? Peg, is he dead?"

JORDYN JAGOLINZER: O`Keefe was found outside of another Boston police officer`s home in Canton in January 2022, where Read says she dropped him off at an after party the night of his death.

PEGGY O`KEEFE: She said, "We went to a party. I left him there." I said, "You just left him there?" She said, "Yes, I just left him there."

JORDYN JAGOLINZER: She said, after leaving the hospital, Read went to her boyfriend`s house.

HANK BRENNAN (Prosecutor): Was there any hugs? Condolences?

PEGGY O`KEEFE: No.

JORDYN JAGOLINZER: The Court also heard testimony from Kerry Roberts, a friend of O`Keefe`s who was with Read when they found his body in the snow.

KERRY ROBERTS (Friend): Karen pointed out and said, "Look my tail light." And I said -- she said, "Do you think I hit him?" And I said, "No, I don`t think you hit him. What are you talking about? Let`s just go find him."

JORDYN JAGOLINZER: The defense pressed Roberts when recalling the condition of Read`s broken tail light in her first conversation with police after O`Keefe`s death.

ALAN JACKSON (Defense attorney): You didn`t mention anything about a tail light or a cracked tail light, or having seen a cracked tail light?

KERRY ROBERTS: No, I did not. No, I did not. I didn`t want to accuse anybody of anything.

JORDYN JAGOLINZER: For CBS MORNINGS, I`m Jordyn Jagolinzer in Dedham, Massachusetts.

(End VT)

GAYLE KING: Coming up, how the investigation of the Gilgo Beach murders may have solved another murder mystery. We`ll have the latest on a case that goes back more than 25 years.

But first, it is 7:17, time to check your local weather.

(LOCAL WEATHER)

(ANNOUNCEMENTS)

RACHEL DUBREUIL: You cannot miss a payment. That then jeopardizes other things that you have to pay for.

NANCY CHEN: Those payments counted towards eventual debt relief under the Public Service Loan Forgiveness Program. The deal: Work for the public sector and student loans would be canceled after 10 years or 120 payments.

To make their payments more affordable, the teachers enrolled in a program known as SAVE which based their loan payments on their incomes.

But last summer, the program was blocked in court, leaving its roughly eight million borrowers in jeopardy. Payments also no longer counted towards debt forgiveness.

RACHEL DUBREUIL: And it was essentially frozen, like our progress was frozen at that point. We`re literally living in this limbo of not knowing where the paperwork is. There`s no phone number, no fax number, no e-mail for them.

NANCY CHEN: As they look to enroll in a new plan, more trouble.

In February, the Department of Education took down online applications for all income driven repayment plans for five weeks. All the applications are now back online, there are processing delays, and Court documents show an outstanding backlog with no clear timeline to clearing it.

In the meantime, borrowers like Dubreuil and Mason are left not knowing when their loans will be forgiven, both within just five payments of the required 120.

What does it mean to be that close and be in limbo right now?

COREY MASON: It`s like heartbreaking. We`ve been working so hard towards like finally being able to say, okay, this debt is done.

RACHEL DUBREUIL: And then now to literally be in the last inches of it and to have it just -- the floor fall out from under us is very painful.

NANCY CHEN: The Education Department said the applications were taken down to revise the forms, and it expects loan providers to resume processing by May 10th. But some advocates say the backlog could still take months or even years to clear.

MIKE PIERCE (Student Borrower Protection Center executive director): This is chaos.

NANCY CHEN: Mike Pierce heads Student Borrower Protection Center, which has filed a lawsuit against the Education Department On behalf of the Union that Dubreuil and Mason belong to.

MIKE PIERCE: They`re stuck in limbo. These public service workers who are doing everything we`ve asked of them, serving in our communities, are stuck in debt, even though they have a legal right to be debt free.

NANCY CHEN: These teachers hope for the loan forgiveness they`ve worked towards, but if it doesn`t come.

RACHEL DUBREUIL It would be catastrophic, because I don`t know where it would come from. We have a little bit of like emergency savings, but beyond that, I don`t know what we would do.

NANCY CHEN: The turmoil happens against the backdrop of steep job cuts in the Education Department, nearly half its workforce.

On top of that, the President plans to move the student loan program to a different agency altogether, a potentially seismic shift as financial futures hang in the balance.

For CBS MORNINGS, Nancy Chen, New York.

GAYLE KING: I don`t eat as much, but I`m always fascinated by it.

NATE BURLESON: Yes, her nickname is the Hamburglar around here. She knows her burgers.

TONY DOKOUPIL: She has driven 500 miles out of her way for a burger.

GAYLE KING: Yes, I have.

SMOKEY ROBINSON: She is the wimpy of the group.

GAYLE KING: That does say something about me. That does.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Well, you`ve got this legacy tour.

GAYLE KING: Yes.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Now, which raises the question of what you want your legacy to be?

NATE BURLESON: Oh, good question.

GAYLE KING: Oh.

SMOKEY ROBINSON: I just hope my legacy is one that people can say that, okay, he was a good human being, you know, who recognized the fact that you don`t get any bigger than being a human being. I don`t care what your craft is or what you do for your living and all that, you know. And people get into show business and they think, Oh, well, you know, this is it. I`m so and so and so.

No, you`re not. You are just a human being, and that`s as big as you`re going to get, you know? So I hope that that`s my legacy.

TONY DOKOUPIL: I also really like the -- you`ve got new versions of iconic songs. "Two Little Birds" is one of favorite songs, but I love your rendition as well.

GAYLE KING: Yes.

TONY DOKOUPIL: What made you want to take on these classics?

SMOKEY ROBINSON: Just the fact that they had sent me a list of great inspirational songs.

NATE BURLESON: Yes.

SMOKEY ROBINSON: And it`s not a spiritual album. This is just inspirational.

So they had sent me this list, and that was one of the songs, I love that. I love Bob Marley. You know, I`m a Bob Marley fan.

NATE BURLESON: Yes.

SMOKEY ROBINSON: So I love the fact that that was even on there, man.

NATE BURLESON: Well, listen --

GAYLE KING: Smokey is still going strong.

NATE BURLESON: -- we appreciate you.

No doubt about it.

GAYLE KING: Yes.

NATE BURLESON: We appreciate your contributions to the industry. And if you listen to music, your fingerprints are all over --

GAYLE KING: Yes.

NATE BURLESON: -- decades and eras of great music. "What the World Needs Now" is out tomorrow, the incredible Smokey Robinson.

GAYLE KING: "What the World Needs Now" is more Smokey.

NATE BURLESON: That`s right.

SMOKEY ROBINSON: Oh.

GAYLE KING: We will see you tomorrow.

TONY DOKOUPIL: Bye.

GAYLE KING: Good to see you.

urn:contentItem:69TJ-NMV1-JBSP-14X0-00000-00Study Findings from Sejong University Update Knowledge in Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (Semantic Segmentation Network Slimming and Edge Deployment for Real-Time Forest Fire or Flood Monitoring Systems Using Unmanned Aerial Vehicles)2023-12-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:24:17ZLexisNexisAVIATION - UNMANNED AERIAL VEHICLEStudy Findings from Sejong University Update Knowledge in Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (Semantic Segmentation Network Slimming and Edge Deployment for Real-Time Forest Fire or Flood Monitoring Systems Using Unmanned Aerial Vehicles)


2023 DEC 07 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Defense & Aerospace Daily -- Fresh data on unmanned aerial vehicle are presented in a new report. According to news reporting out of Seoul, South Korea, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "In recent years, there has been a significant increase in the demand for unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-based monitoring systems to ensure proper emergency response during natural disasters such as wildfires, hurricanes, floods, and earthquakes."


Financial supporters for this research include Ministry of Education.
The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Sejong University: "This paper proposes a real-time UAV monitoring system for responding to forest fires or floods. The proposed system consists of a hardware part and a software part. The hardware configuration is an embedded camera board mounted on the UAV, a Qualcomm QCS610 SoC with cores suitable for running deep learning-based algorithms. The software configuration is a deep learning-based semantic segmentation model for detecting fires or floods. To execute the model in real time on edge devices with limited resources, we used a network slimming technique which generates a lightweight model with reduced model size, number of parameters, and computational complexity. The performance of the proposed system was evaluated on the FLAME dataset consisting of forest fire images and the FloodNet dataset consisting of flood images."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The experimental results showed that the mIoU of slimmed DeepLabV3+ for FLAME is 88.29%, and the inference speed is 10.92 fps. For FloodNet, the mIoU of the slimmed DeepLabV3+ is 94.15%, and the inference speed is 13.26 fps. These experimental results confirm that the proposed system is appropriate for accurate, low-power, real-time monitoring of forest fires and floods using UAVs."
For more information on this research see: Semantic Segmentation Network Slimming and Edge Deployment for Real-Time Forest Fire or Flood Monitoring Systems Using Unmanned Aerial Vehicles. Electronics, 2023,12(23). (Electronics - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/electronics). The publisher for Electronics is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/electronics12234795.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Youn Joo Lee, Department of Intelligent Mechatronics Engineering, Sejong University, Seoul 05006, South Korea. Additional authors for this research include Ho Gi Jung, Jae Kyu Suhr.

urn:contentItem:6C1N-VD11-DY7R-R1CT-00000-00Jiangxi Normal University Researcher Provides New Study Findings on Machine Learning (Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning-Based Predictive Models for Fine Dead Fuel Moisture of Subtropical Forest in China)2024-05-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:24:17ZLexisNexisMACHINE LEARNINGJiangxi Normal University Researcher Provides New Study Findings on Machine Learning (Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning-Based Predictive Models for Fine Dead Fuel Moisture of Subtropical Forest in China)


2024 MAY 15 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Robotics & Machine Learning Daily News Daily News -- Researchers detail new data in artificial intelligence. According to news originating from Nanchang, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "The moisture content of fine dead surface fuel in forests is a crucial metric for assessing its combustibility and plays a pivotal role in the early warning, occurrence, and spread of forest fires. Accurate prediction of the moisture content of fine dead fuel on the forest surface is a critical challenge in forest fire management."


Financial supporters for this research include National Natural Science Foundation of China; Jiangxi Provincial Department of Education Graduate Innovation Fund.
Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Jiangxi Normal University: "Previous research on fine surface fuel moisture content has been mainly focused on coniferous forests in cold temperate zones, but there has been less attention given to understanding the fuel moisture dynamics in subtropical forests, which limits the development of regional forest fire warning models. Here, we consider the coupled influence of multiple meteorological, terrain, forest stand, and other characteristic factors on the fine dead fuel moisture content within the subtropical evergreen broadleaved forest region of southern China. The ability of five machine learning algorithms to predict the moisture content of fine dead fuel on the forest surface is assessed, and the key factors affecting the model accuracy are identified. Results show that when a single meteorological factor is used as a forecasting model, its forecasting accuracy is less than that of the combined model with multiple characteristic factors. However, the prediction accuracy of the model is improved after the addition of forest stand factors and terrain factors. The model prediction ability is the best for the combination of all feature factors including meteorology, forest stand, and terrain."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "The overall prediction accuracy of the model is ordered as follows: random forest > extreme gradient boosting > support vector machine > stepwise linear regression > k-nearest neighbor. Canopy density in forest stand factors, slope position and altitude in terrain factors, and average relative air humidity and light intensity in the previous 15 days are the key meteorological factors affecting the prediction accuracy of fuel moisture content. Our results provide scientific guidance and support for understanding the variability of forest surface fuel moisture content and improved regional forest fire warnings."
For more information on this research see: Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning-Based Predictive Models for Fine Dead Fuel Moisture of Subtropical Forest in China. Forests, 2024,15(5). (Forests - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/forests/). The publisher for Forests is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/f15050736.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Xiang Hou, Key Laboratory of Poyang Lake Wetland and Watershed Research, Ministry of Education, Jiangxi Normal University, Nanchang 330022, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Zhiwei Wu, Shihao Zhu, Zhengjie Li, Shun Li.

urn:contentItem:6CNY-FPC1-JC0C-J002-00000-00ONLY HE2024-08-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:24:17ZLexisNexisDPg. 007ONLY HECharles Apple The Spokesman-Review

FURTHER REVIEW

When the U.S. Forest Service needed a symbol to draw the nation's attention to the danger of wildfires, Uncle Sam just wouldn't do. Bambi, despite his success in a popular Disney movie, wouldn't do, either.

Only Smokey Bear - a little bear cub who was found aftera forest fire 80 years ago Friday - could do the job.

1937

President Franklin D. Roosevelt launches a national campaign to reduce forest fires. Posters featuring Uncle Sam as a forest ranger tell people "Our forests - Our fault."

1942

A Japanese submarine surfaces off the coast and fires on an oil field near Santa Barbara, Calif. Damage is minimal, but officials realize Los Padres National Forest is at risk. With resources at a premium during wartime, fire safety becomes an even higher priority.

1944

Disney makes a one-year deal to loan Bambi and his friends to the forest fire prevention campaign. The campaign is a success, but ad executives realize they need an animal symbol of their own.

AUG. 9

A new campaign is launched featuring a bear. The first poster, drawn pro bono by illustrator Albert Staehle, shows a character he calls Smokey pouring water on a campfire. He says he started with a raccoon but thought it looked too much "like a bandit.

1947

The very successful Smokey Bear campaign continues in the postwar years with the new slogan, "Only you."

1950

MAY 9

A group of firefighters narrowly escapes disaster near Capitan, N.M., by taking refuge on a rock slide as the fire burns over them.

Afterward, they find a bear cub - his fur singed and his paws badly burned - clinging to a charred tree. Named Hotfoot Teddy, the cub is nursed back to health by a New Mexico game warden and his family.

JUNE 27

Now famous, the cub is flown to the National Zoo in Washing ton, D.C., to become the living embodiment of Smokey Bear. The U.S. Postal Service eventually gives Smokey his own ZIP code when he begins receiving up to 13,000 letters a week.

1952

A song, "Smokey the Bear" - written by Steve Nelson and Jack Rollins, the same guys who wrote "Peter Cottontail" and "Frosty the Snowman" - becomes a big hit. Rollins adds "the" to Smokey's name to make the lyrics fit better. As a result, a generation or two of children grow up calling the character "Smokey the Bear" instead of just "Smokey Bear."

MAY 23

Congress passes the Smokey Bear Act, taking Smokey out of the public domain and preserving the trademark for the U.S. Department of Agriculture. More important, the move earmarks revenue from sales of Smokey toys and memorabilia for fire prevention awareness efforts.

1971

A new cub, Little Smokey, joins Smokey in the National Zoo. He, too, was born in a New Mexico forest andrescued from starvation by park rangers.

1975

MAY 2 Smokey, old and arthritic and still suffering from his injuries, is officially retired from public service. LittleSmokey is officially named his successor as "Smokey II."

1976

NOV. 9

Smokey dies at age 26. His remains are flown back to near where he was found in New Mexico. More than 250 people attend his memorial service. Two days after the funeral, an obituary runs on Page 1 of the Wall Street Journal.

1979

Smokey Bear Historical Park is completed near Capitan, at the grave of the originalSmokey. The park includes a museum.

1990

AUG. 11

Smokey II dies.

2020

While both Smokey and Smokey II have died, the character lives on. Recent ads feature Smokey seeking out people who exhibit safe behavior and rewarding them with - what else? - a bear hug.

Sources: The Ad Council, U.S. Department of Agriculture, U.S. Forest Service, the Metis Group, the Smithsonian Institution, the Washington Post, ABC News, NewMexicoWatchdog.org, New Mexico Energy, Minerals and Natural Resources Department, West Virginia Humanities Council, Marjory Houston, About.com

urn:contentItem:68WS-4T71-DY7R-R3HR-00000-00Research from Nanjing Forestry University in the Area of Remote Sensing Described (Weakly Supervised Forest Fire Segmentation in UAV Imagery Based on Foreground-Aware Pooling and Context-Aware Loss)2023-08-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:24:17ZLexisNexisTECHNOLOGY - REMOTE SENSINGResearch from Nanjing Forestry University in the Area of Remote Sensing Described (Weakly Supervised Forest Fire Segmentation in UAV Imagery Based on Foreground-Aware Pooling and Context-Aware Loss)


2023 AUG 08 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Tech Daily News -- New study results on remote sensing have been published. According to news reporting originating from Nanjing, People's Republic of China, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, "In recent years, tragedies caused by forest fires have been frequently reported. Forest fires not only result in significant economic losses but also cause environmental damage."


Funders for this research include Chinese Academy of Forestry; Zhejiang Science And Technology Major Program on Agricultural New Variety Breeding; Postgraduate Research & Practice Innovation Program of Jiangsu Province.
The news journalists obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing Forestry University: "The utilization of computer vision techniques and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) for forest fire monitoring has become a primary approach to accurately locate and extinguish fires during their early stages. However, traditional computer-based methods for UAV forest fire image segmentation require a large amount of pixel-level labeled data to train the networks, which can be time-consuming and costly to acquire. To address this challenge, we propose a novel weakly supervised approach for semantic segmentation of fire images in this study. Our method utilizes self-supervised attention foreground-aware pooling (SAP) and context-aware loss (CAL) to generate high-quality pseudo-labels, serving as substitutes for manual annotation. SAP collaborates with bounding box and class activation mapping (CAM) to generate a background attention map, which aids in the generation of accurate pseudo-labels. CAL further improves the quality of the pseudo-labels by incorporating contextual information related to the target objects, effectively reducing environmental noise."
According to the news reporters, the research concluded: "We conducted experiments on two publicly available UAV forest fire datasets: the Corsican dataset and the Flame dataset. Our proposed method achieved impressive results, with IoU values of 81.23% and 76.43% for the Corsican dataset and the Flame dataset, respectively. These results significantly outperform the latest weakly supervised semantic segmentation (WSSS) networks on forest fire datasets."
For more information on this research see: Weakly Supervised Forest Fire Segmentation in UAV Imagery Based on Foreground-Aware Pooling and Context-Aware Loss. Remote Sensing, 2023,15(14). (Remote Sensing - http://www.mdpi.com/journal/remotesensing/). The publisher for Remote Sensing is MDPI AG.
A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.3390/rs15143606.
Our news editors report that additional information may be obtained by contacting Junling Wang, College of information Science and Technology, Nanjing Forestry University, Nanjing 210037, People's Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Yupeng Wang, Liping Liu, Hengfu Yin, Ning Ye, Can Xu.
ORCID is an identifier for authors and includes bibliographic information. The following is ORCID information for the author of this research: Ning Ye (orcid.org/0000-0001-7249-8352).

urn:contentItem:6DDK-VPB1-DY7P-T3K2-00000-00New York drought conditions fan flames, spur water saving2024-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:24:17ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1New York drought conditions fan flames, spur water saving

New York has urged its 8.5 million residents to save water as America's biggest city endures an unprecedented period without significant rainfall, creating potentially dangerous drought conditions and fanning the flames of deadly wildfires.

Since Friday, wildfires have burned through thousands of acres on the border between New York and New Jersey, just an hour from Manhattan, claiming the life of an 18-year-old firefighter battling the blazes.

On the New York side, officials said the fire was the largest on record since 2008, fueled by dry winds.

New York and other parts of the state north of the city are under a red flag warning for bush and forest fires with high winds, low humidity and dry conditions creating tinderbox conditions.

There was even a small fire over the weekend in New York's Prospect Park, a large green space in the city's densely populated Brooklyn borough, although it was quickly extinguished.

"The reality is, the drought that we're currently experiencing is just one example of how a changing climate is impacting our state today, not far off into the future, but right now," said New Jersey Governor Phil Murphy.

New York City and the surrounding region have gone without significant rainfall for much of September and October, and November has been mostly dry so far.

- Perfect storm -

The drought-like conditions have coincided with a major overhaul of New York's water supply system, which has seen the city source more from a reservoir in Catskill Park, located in an area particularly affected by the dry conditions.

"While there is plenty of water in our reservoirs now, we are working to start public conservation efforts now in case this drought continues," the city's department of environmental protection said in a statement.

More from this section

From 'Little Marco' to 'Mr Secretary': Rubio shows Trump China push

Prehistoric 'bird brain' fossil reveals evolution of avian intelligence

'London's best-kept secret': UK's largest wholesale market turns 50

The city's fire department has called on residents to flag leaking fire hydrants so they can be closed, warning in an Instagram post that "an open hydrant can release more than 1,000 gallons per minute."

New York City's average daily water demand has decreased by approximately 35 percent in recent decades, but officials say more can be done to avoid waste, calling on residents to only flush toilets when necessary and to take shorter showers.

The reservoirs relied on by the city, which are usually filled by rainfall in October and November, are only 62 percent full -- far less than the normal level of about 79.2 percent.

The Office of Natural Lands Management said that the ground in parts of New Jersey was dry almost eight inches down -- the worst situation in more than 100 years -- meaning it would require that many inches of rainfall to bring the soil back to saturation.

There is no rainfall forecast in the area this week, and parts of New York have imposed a drought watch -- two steps below a drought emergency at which point homes and businesses are forced to restrict water use. 

Drought-hit areas of New Jersey are already one notch above New York's, at the drought warning stage.

"The impact of this on wildfires cannot be overstated," said Greg McLaughlin, chief of the New Jersey Forest Fire Service, which has responded to 537 wildfires so far this year -- 500 more than in the same period last year.

Brian Fuchs, a climatologist at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, said it had been over 20 years since a similar drought episode in the northeastern United States.

"One of the attributes that is starting to come out (with climate change) is these rapid transitions from either very wet periods to very dry periods, or very dry periods to very wet periods," he said.

urn:contentItem:692M-XPH1-JDKC-R10B-00000-00GIFFORD PINCHOT NATIONAL FOREST FIRE UPDATE2023-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:24:17ZLexisNexisGIFFORD PINCHOT NATIONAL FOREST FIRE UPDATE

VANCOUVER, Wash., Aug. 29 -- The U.S. Department of Agriculture's U.S. Forest Service unit - Gifford Pinchot National Forest - issued the following press release:

A number of fires burning on the Gifford Pinchot National Forest are now being called the Cowlitz Complex. The Rocky Mountain Complex Incident Management Team 2 will take command of the complex of fires at 6am on Wednesday, Aug. 30 and will be based out of Randle, WA. A community meeting is being planned for next week.

A strong cold front is passing through the region today bringing with it increasing moisture and rainfall. This will help reduce fire activity. However, gusty winds are expected with the passing front, which may increase fire activity.

Fire suppression resources are being committed only where they have high probability of success and can operate safely and effectively. Firefighters continue to engage with fire suppression efforts on numerous fires around the forest making headway on containment on several of the new fires. Resources assigned to these fires now exceed 250 personnel with additional support anticipated in the coming days.
